values:
to happen; to start to exist (especially of a problem or a difficult situation)
to get up from bed, or to stand up (literary or old use)

to wake up; to make someone wake up
if an emotion awakes or something awakes an emotion, you start to feel that emotion

to exist; to be present (linking verb)
to be located; to be in a place
to be able to accept and deal with something unpleasant (usually in negatives or questions)
to hit someone or something many times, usually very hard
to start to be something (linking verb)

to start happening or existing
to start doing something; to do the first part of something

to move the top part of your body forwards and downwards
to become curved or folded and not straight
to risk money on a race or an event by trying to predict the result

to tie someone or something with rope or string
to unite people or organizations so that they live or work together more happily or effectively

to use your teeth to cut or break something, usually in order to eat it
to wound someone by making a small hole or mark in their skin (of snakes, insects)
to lose blood, especially from a wound or an injury

to send out air from the mouth
if wind or air blows, the air moves

to make something separate into two or more pieces, for example by hitting or dropping it
to stop working as a result of being damaged; to damage something and stop it from working
to do something that is against the law

to come to a place with someone or something
to get something for someone and give it to them
to send out programmes on television or radio

This verb can also be used as a regular verb (more often in American English): broadcast – broadcasted – broadcasted. However, irregular forms broadcast – broadcast – broadcast are more common than regular ones.

to make something, especially a building, by putting parts together
to create or develop something

to produce flames and heat
to damage or destroy something with fire
Irregular forms burn – burnt – burnt are common in British English. In American English it is used as a regular verb burn – burned – burned.

to break open or apart, especially because of pressure from inside
to make something break in this way
to get something by paying money for it

to choose an actor for a particular part in a film or play
to look at someone or something in a particular way
to throw someone or something somewhere, especially using force (literary)

to stop someone or something that is moving through the air by getting hold of it
to find and stop a person or animal who is trying to escape
to decide which thing you want

to hold someone or something tightly, especially because you are frightened
to stick to something

to move to or towards a person or place
to arrive somewhere or go to a place
if someone creeps somewhere, they move there quietly and slowly

to remove something or a part of something, using a knife
to injure a part of your body with something sharp that cuts the skin

to give cards to players in a game
to buy and sell illegal drugs

to make a hole in the ground or to move soil from one place to another using your hands, a tool or a machine
to remove something from the ground with a tool
to work at or perform an activity or a task

to produce a picture by making lines or marks, usually with a pen or pencil
to move something or someone by pulling it or them gently

to experience events and images in your mind while you are sleeping
to imagine and think about something that you would like to happen
Irregular forms dream – dreamt – dreamt are common in British English. In American English it is used as a regular verb dream – dreamed – dreamed.
to take liquid into your mouth and swallow it

to operate a vehicle so that it goes in a particular direction
to take someone somewhere in a car, taxi

to put food in your mouth, chew it and swallow it
to have a meal

to drop down from a higher level to a lower level
to become lower in level, amount, or value
to give food to a person or an animal

to experience an emotion or a physical feeling (linking verb)
to touch something with your hand so that you can discover what it is like

to take part in a war or battle against an enemy
to struggle physically with somebody
to try hard to stop, deal with or oppose something bad

to discover something, or to see where it is by searching for it
to discover something or someone by chance
to have a particular feeling or opinion about something

to be the right shape and size for someone or something (never progressive)
to put or fix something somewhere

This verb is used as a regular verb in British English: fit – fitted – fitted. Irregular forms fit – fit – fit are common in American English. However, fit is not used in NAmE as the past participle in the passive.
to escape from a dangerous situation or place very quickly

to throw something carelessly or with a lot of force
to move yourself or part of your body suddenly and with a lot of force

to move through the air, using wings (of birds or insects)
to move through air or space
to travel by plane

to order someone not to do something
to state that something is not allowed, according to a rule, law, or custom
to say what you expect to happen in the future

to be unable to remember a fact or piece of information
to not remember to do something that you intended to do
to decide that you will not be angry with someone who has offended, upset, or harmed you

if water freezes, or if something freezes it, it gets very cold and changes into ice
to preserve food or drink by making it extremely cold in a freezer

to obtain, receive or be given something (never passive)
to go to a place and bring someone or something back
In spoken American English the past participle gotten [ɡɑːtn] is almost always used.

to put something in someone’s hand, or to pass something to someone
to provide someone with something

to move or travel from one place to another
to leave one place in order to reach another
to visit or attend a place for a particular purpose

to increase in size, number, strength or quality
to become bigger or taller and develop into an adult (of people or animals)
if plants or trees grow, they develop and get larger or taller

to attach something, or to be attached, at the top so that the lower part is free or loose
to attach something, especially a picture, to a hook on a wall
to own, hold or possess something (not used in the progressive tenses)

to be aware of sounds with your ears (never progressive)
to receive information about something (not usually progressive)

to put something in a place where it cannot be seen or found
to go to a place where you cannot be seen or found

to move quickly onto an object or surface, touching it with force
to affect something badly

to carry something using your hands or arms
to keep someone or something in a particular position

to feel pain somewhere in your body
to cause physical pain or injury
to make someone unhappy or upset

to stay in a state, position, or place without changing or moving
to do something many times, or to continue doing it
to continue to have or own something
to put one or both knees on the ground
Irregular forms kneel – knelt – knelt are common in British English. In American English this verb is also used as a regular verb: kneel – kneeled – kneeled.

to make clothes using wool and two long needles to join the wool into rows
to join people or things closely together or to be joined closely together

This verb is more often used as a regular verb both in British and American English: knit – knitted – knitted. The irregular form knit is usually used in the following meanings of the verb: ‘to join people or things closely together’ or ‘to grow together again to form one piece (of broken bones)’.

to have knowledge or information about something in your mind
to be familiar with a person, place, thing
to feel certain about something

to put someone or something down in a careful way
to put something into its correct position

to show someone the way to a place by going there with them
to go in a particular direction or to a particular place

to bend or move from a vertical position
to rest on or against something for support

In American English this verbs is used as a regular verb: lean – leaned – leaned. Irregular forms lean – leant – leant are common in British English. However, it can be used as a regular verb in British English too.

to jump high or a long way
to move or do something suddenly and quickly
to suddenly improve, increase, or progress
This verb is also used as a regular verb both in British and American English: leap – leaped – leaped. However, the irregular forms leap – leapt – leapt are more common in British English.

to gain knowledge or experience of something
to study and repeat something in order to be able to remember it
to gain new information about a situation, event, or person
The irregular forms learn – learnt – learnt are more common in British English. In American English this verb is used as a regular verb: learn – learned – learned.

to go away from a person or a place
to stop living at a place, belonging to a group, working for an employer
to put something somewhere, especially in a place where it will stay
to give someone something for a short time, expecting that they will give it back to you later.

to allow something to happen
to give someone permission to do something

to be in a position in which your body is flat on a surface (of a person or an animal)
to be or remain in a flat position on a surface (of a thing)

to make something start to burn
to give light to something or to a place

The irregular forms light – lit – lit are more often used both in British and American English. However, this verb can also be used as a regular verb: light – lighted – lighted. Lighted is usually used for the past participle, especially in front of nouns: a lighted road.

to be unable to find something or someone
to stop having something because it has been taken from you or destroyed
to not win a race, competition, fight

to create or produce something by working
to cause someone or something to be in a particular state
to cause someone or something to do something

to have a particular meaning
to intend to express a fact or opinion
to have a particular result

to come to the same place as someone else by arrangement or by chance
to see and speak to someone for the first time
to cut grass using a machine or tool with blades
to give someone money for work, goods, services

to move something into a particular place or position
to write something or make a mark on something
to cause someone or something to be in a particular situation

to leave a job or school permanently
to stop doing something

to look at words and understand what they mean
to discover or find out about someone or something by reading

to travel by sitting on a horse, bicycle, or motorcycle and controlling it
to travel in a vehicle, especially as a passenger

to call someone by telephone
to make a bell produce a sound
to make a continuous loud high sound

to move upwards or to a higher position
to get up from a lying, sitting or kneeling position
to increase in size, amount, quality, or strength

to move quickly to a place using your legs and feet
to control and organize something such as a business, organization, or event
if a machine or engine runs, or if you run it, it is working
to cut something with a saw

to express something using words
to express an opinion on something
to give information in writing, numbers, or signs

to notice someone or something using your eyes (never progressive)
to meet or visit someone who you know by arrangement
to understand something (never progressive)

to look for something or someone
to try to obtain or achieve something

to exchange something for money
to offer something for people to buy

to post a letter or parcel to someone
to tell someone something by sending them a message

to put someone or something in a position
to make a piece of equipment ready to operate
to arrange a time when something will happen

to use a needle and thread to make stitches in cloth
to make or repair clothes using a needle and thread

to make lots of quick small movements up and down, or side to side
to move your head from side to side to mean 'no'

to produce or reflect light; to be bright
to have a bright attractive appearance

to fire a gun or other weapon
to kill or wound a person or an animal with a bullet

to make something clear; to prove something
to let someone see something

to become smaller in size
to become smaller in amount, value, or range
to close something, for example a door, window, or drawer

to make music using your voice
to make high musical sounds (of birds)

to disappear below the surface of the water
to move to a lower level

to rest your weight on your bottom with your back vertical, for example on/in a chair
to put someone in a sitting position
to rest with your eyes closed and your mind and body not active

to move smoothly and quickly across a surface
to move quickly without anyone noticing you

to throw something somewhere with force or in a careless way
to put something somewhere where it hangs loosely (often passive)

to have a particular smell
to notice or recognize the smell of something (never progressive)
to experience the smell of something by putting your nose close to it
The irregular forms smell – smelt – smelt are common in British English. In American English this verb is used as a regular verb: smell – smelled – smelled.
to plant seeds in the ground

to talk to someone about something
to use your voice to talk
to be able to talk in a particular language

to move quickly
to drive a car faster than the fastest speed legally allowed
to say or write the letters of a word in the correct order
This verb is also used as a regular verb (more often in American English): spell – spelled – spelled. The irregular forms spell – spelt – spelt are more common in British English.

to use money to pay for things
to use time doing something or being somewhere
to accidentally pour a liquid out of its container

to turn round and round quickly; to make something do this
to make thread by twisting together cotton, wool
You can also meet the form span for the past simple tense. This form is archaic both in British and American English. However, span is still used in contemporary British English but very rarely.
to force liquid, food, etc. out of your mouth
The irregular forms spit – spit – spit are also sometimes used in American English.

to divide into smaller groups, or to divide people into smaller groups
to make a long thin cut or break in something

to change something good into something bad, unpleasant, useless
to always allow a child to have or do everything that they want
to treat someone with a lot of care and kindness

In American English this verb is used as a regular verb: spoil – spoiled – spoiled. The irregular forms spoil – spoilt – spoilt are more common in British English. However, the regular forms are used in British English too.

to gradually affect or cover a larger area
to cause someone or something to be in a number of different places

to jump or move in a particular direction, quickly and with a lot of energy
to happen or appear somewhere suddenly or unexpectedly

to be in a vertical position on your feet
to move from sitting or bending down into an upright position
to take something that belongs to someone else without permission

to push something long and thin into or through something else
to fix one thing to another, especially using a sticky substance such as glue

to touch your skin or make a very small hole in it so that you feel a sharp pain (of insects, plants)
to have or cause a sudden pain or uncomfortable feeling

to have a strong, unpleasant smell
to seem very bad, unpleasant or dishonest

to hit someone or something hard or with force
to refuse to work, because of a disagreement over pay or conditions
to try very hard to achieve something

to use rude or offensive language, usually because you are angry
to make a serious promise to do something

to clean the floor using a brush
to remove something from a surface using a brush, your hand
to move or spread quickly through an area

to become bigger or rounder
to increase or make something increase in number or size
to move through water by making movements with your arms and legs

to move smoothly backwards and forwards, or to make something do this
to move or make something move with a wide curved movement

to move something or someone from one place to another
to cause someone to move somewhere
to accept something that someone offers you

to help students to learn something in a school, college, university by giving lessons
to show or explain to someone how to do something

to pull something so that it separates into pieces or gets a hole in it
to become damaged in this way
to remove something by pulling it away from something else with force

to give information to someone by speaking or writing
to give information about something
to order or strongly advise someone to do something

to believe something based on facts or ideas
to have a particular opinion about someone or something
to consider an idea or a problem

to use your hand to send an object through the air
to put something somewhere in a quick careless way
to move your body or part of it quickly or suddenly
to put something somewhere with a quick hard push

to put your foot down while you are stepping or walking (especially British)
to crush or press something with your feet

to know what someone or something means
to know why or how something happens or works
to know how someone feels or why they behave in a particular way

to stop sleeping
to make someone stop sleeping

to have something on your body as clothing, decoration, or protection
to have a particular expression on your face
to make cloth on a machine by crossing threads under and over each other
to cry because you feel unhappy or have some other strong emotion
to make something wet with water or another liquid
In British English this verb is also used as a regular verb: wet – wetted – wetted.

to defeat everyone else by being the best or by finishing first in a competition
to achieve or get something that you want, especially by your own efforts

to wrap or twist something around itself or around something else
to have many bends and twists
to twist and squeeze something in order to remove liquid from it

to use a pen to make words, numbers, or symbols
to create something such as a story or song by putting words together
